title: Production Issues !
content:
I’ve had a type filled weekend so far!!! I got my copy of Goudys Trajan Capitals Book, a cute little P22 catalog and a FontShop 2004/2005 addendum. Wait. 04.05 ? Anyway.

I need some advice in mocking something up. I attached a pdf of the page cover in question. I’d like to mock it up how I spec’d it for the project, colored paper with 3 colors on the front, one of which is white. When I turned it in before I did the whole photoquality epson matte paper on boards, but I have an interview (!) the week of the 22nd and would like to have it lookin’ good. So the question is, without screen printing, is it possible to mock up a hit of white ink on colored paper ?

See pdf.

Thx everyone

author: Eric_West

comments.content:
Classy.

—

Roman numerals: too big.

“2004”: make 3/4 lining.

Price: point too loose - but really, it could be classier; try making the “95” superscript, with some mark under it. And can you make it $8?

Will you be tweaking the spacing on the all-caps? It’s all over the place.

hhp

Mock-up white: I would have used custom dry-transfer (too long ago to mention) — does anyone still do that?

On the type, I would recommend using regular Perpetua for the slightly smaller size, for an “optical” scaling effect.

Thanks guys,

I do have an airbrush sitting in the basement … Hmmm… tricky, but it might work… Stencil with spaces left out for letters… Liquid frisket maybe ?
There are one-off printers that can do an opaque white. Call around. Many market themselves as doing high-end comps of packaging. The printers are ink-jets with a white cart.

Why wouldn’t you screen print it? With a high resolution frame ( :-) ) it might just work, no? Plus screen printed stuff is sweet. :)

I’d check the spacing, too. The different words have different spacing and there’s variation inside them, too.

Hrant: Why wouldn’t you use old style numerals? It is ‘.75 times the H height’ high numbers you are suggesting, right?

\> Why wouldn’t you use old style numerals?

Normally I would, but in the context of the top two lines, and how the roman  
numerals [need to] look, lining (yes, between the x-height and caps) seems to  
make more sense.

hhp

The text at the bottom is off center.  
“journal of contemporary home & garden”

Mikey

I’m a little late to the game, and this has nothing to do with producing a mock-up with white, but - despite the simplicity of the design - does no one else find the typography busy? Or the blackletter a closed fist to the face?

The latter is way too overbearing to my mind and is effectively screaming at me (sshhhhhh). At the very least I think I’d pull the tint back a bit.

The former has too many competing styles going on: the top italics, the middle caps, the bottom caption; each of these three units has a different personality, and they’re jockying too much for distinction. Any reason that these three units aren’t in the same type?

Also, there is a weight issue with the small-cap/all-cap setting in the middle. Are those small-caps? Or just smaller caps?

Diecut vinyl should serve for the mock-up, but for a better effect do a google for custom rubdown lettering, somewhere like this would suit for the frame (or if you get the whole lot made up into a composite rubdown you could then apply it to a sheet, get at least two though, because it can be tricky stuff if you’re not used to it).  
 [http://www.allout-graphics.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20060523165131/http:/www.allout-graphics.com/)

Just as an aside do you intend for the image to print in white as an overprint, if so you should be able to get an inkjet to print the 4 colour breakdown onto the coloured paper to simulate it.

Tim

[http://www.virtualpackaging.com/index2.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20060523165131/http:/www.virtualpackaging.com/index2.htm)
